utterances: Law enforcement officials and other Muslim leaders say the problem is more serious.
They are worried outliers like the Thinkers will tar all Muslims in New York with an extremist brush.
Because Muslim youths are suppose to take guidance from their religious elders, religious leaders in Muslim groups in New York are certain they'll be able to defuse the situation.
For NPR News, I'm Dina Temple-Raston.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Debbie Elliott.
Time now for some of your letters.
And let's start with a correction.
Last week on our program, we discussed evangelical Christian leadership with NPR's religion correspondent Barbara Bradley Hagerty.
We mistakenly identified James Dobson as a pastor.
Dobson is a licensed psychologist and speaks about evangelical beliefs on his radio program ""Focus On The Family,"" but he is not an ordained minister.
Several listeners commented on our segment on the literary adventures of the Gentleman Thief, Arsene Lupin, and quotes wrote in all the way Tokyo.
You mentioned that Arsene Lupin is not well known to Americans.
Many Americans, however, know Arsene's famous grandson, Lupin III.
The character, central to a television animation and movie series, is a cultural icon in Japan.
Perhaps fans of Lupin III will be interested in the adventures of his more suave and possibly more learned ancestor.
Also in the literary vein, Janine Blaylock(ph) in Seattle heard our remembrance of children's author Lloyd Alexander, who died a few weeks ago.
The heroics and humor in his books kept bringing me back, she wrote.
As an adult, I came to see the subtler gift Alexander gave this reader - a love of words and an appreciation for elegant writing.
And finally, Jackie Lyden's tribute to her great aunt Ellie Lyden on her birthday, inspired this comment from listener Patricia McCann(ph) in Pittsburgh.
I truly enjoyed and was touched by your story on the woman in Clifton, Ireland celebrating her 100th birthday.
I love the Irishness of it.
Could picture her cottage on the Galway Road, and the recognition of spiritual motherhood as well as physical motherhood.
I suspect that most of us either know such a woman in our own lives or are that woman in someone else's life.
How lovely.
We always want to hear from you, so if you have questions, comments or critiques, drop us a line.
Go to our Web site, npr.org.
Click on Contact Us and select WEEKEND ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
Southern Utah does not have a traffic problem, like we've just heard about in New York.
It does have some serious bicycle riders, both mountain bikes and road bikes.
As a result, it is home to a hard-working crew of bike mechanics and it's the source of today's Soundclip.
My name is Ron George and I am the senior mechanic at Poison Spider Bicycles in Moab, Utah.
(Soundbite of a caliper chiming)
If you ask people what it is they love about bicycling or about, in particular, their bicycle, they're not going to say much about the noise it makes.
In fact, if it is making a noise, they're going to come in with a complaint.
(Soundbite of a caliper chiming)
When we're diagnosing the wheel, we put in a, they call it truing stand, which has a caliper much like a rim break.
And that caliper is metal.
So when it contacts the metal surface of the rim, it chimes.
(Soundbite of a caliper chiming)
Once we've made the wheel true again, we want to make sure that all of those spokes are in perfect tension.
To check their tension, one of techniques is simply to spin the wheel around and run the back of your thumbnail against the spokes.
(Soundbite of spokes chiming)
A bicycle can deliver your power with 97 percent efficiency.
That is to say the amount of wattage you're putting out at the pedal can be delivered to the ground with only a three-percent loss.
(Soundbite of cycling)
Ron George is a bicycle mechanic in Moab, Utah.
When President Bush's domestic policy advisor Claude Allen resigned suddenly on February 9th, he said he wanted to spend more time with his family.
This weekend, that resignation came into sharper focus.
Allen was arrested last Thursday and charged in a felony theft scheme called refund fraud.
Washington Post reporter Michael Fletcher says Allen was first caught in early January.
So why did Sinclair order its anchors to do this?
What's the message here?
The Metropolitan Police today released a picture from a video camera for the first time showing all four bombers together.
In it, Hasib Hussain, Shehzad Tanweer, Germaine Lindsey and Mohammed Sidique Khan are seen entering the Luton train station en route to London to carry out their attacks.
Khan's family issued a statement earlier today saying they were devastated to learn that their son had been brainwashed into committing such an act.
This followed similar remarks by Hasib Hussain's family on Friday.
Anthony Kuhn, NPR News, London.
As the climate changes, certain plants and animals are ranging farther south or farther north.
We do not know if that is precisely why an alligator, a reptile well-known in the southern United States, turned up in Chicago's Humboldt Park lagoon.
Chance the Snapper was the name given to the alligator after a contest on social media.
A week-long chase for him was first led by a volunteer nicknamed Alligator Bob.
Of course.
But eventually city officials brought in Frank Robb, who is an alligator expert from Florida.
He captured Chance with his fishing pole.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Once we were able to see him, was one cast and done.
Sure, simple - 5-foot-3 alligator, what could go wrong?
The alligator, he says, did put up a little bit of a fight.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
People ask you how you catch an alligator.
Just barely is the answer because it's usually just barely.
Robb says this is the first alligator he has caught outside of Florida.
And Chance sent Chicago into a frenzy.
One guy tried to lure the gator with a rotisserie chicken.
(Laughter).
A police officer blared the ""Jaws"" theme song from his cruiser.
(Singing) Ba-duh, duh (ph).
People made alligator T-shirts and tote bags.
And musicians even recorded a song about it.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""EL COCODRILO DE HUMBOLDT PARK"")
(Singing in Spanish).
They are singing that the gator in the park does not have teeth.
After he was captured, Chance the Snapper appeared at a press conference wearing a plaid bow tie.
We don't know who did that to him.
But Chance has been given a clean bill of health.
And according to Chicago Animal Care and Control, he'll be transferred to an animal sanctuary.
Whew.
